prompt:
There are many variables used in this experiment. Identify which variables are the dependent and which are independent.

(a)
Body temperature:
![dropdown:body_temperature]

(b)
Pulse rate:
![dropdown:pulse_rate]

(c)
Water temperature:
![dropdown:water_temperature]
description:
The theory of homeostasis says the body has several processes that respond to each other in order to maintain the body at its normal condition, such as maintaining a body temperature of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit (37°C). Some students are conducting an experiment to determine if heart rate and blood pressure help regulate body temperature.

Their hypothesis is that if the body is exposed to hot temperatures the heart rate and blood pressure will increase in order to reduce body temperature to normal. To conduct the experiment, the test subject will place both arms into a tub of hot water at 120 degrees Fahrenheit, about the temperature of a hot shower. To gather data, the students plan to use a thermometer to measure skin temperature of the arm in the water tub. Another thermometer will measure the body temperature in the mouth. An electronic blood pressure cuff will take frequent measurements of pulse rate and blood pressure.
feedback: <show correct answer graphic> Of the 6 variables listed, water temperature is the independent variable. This is the variable the scientists can control and then observe how other variables change depending on the water temperature. The dependent variables are blood pressure, body temperature, and pulse rate. The number of subjects and number of scientists are not variables within the experiment.
